questions.text: Donald Duck and José Carioca played key roles in the short musical movie, "Blame it on the _____". What dance music is missing from the title?
questions.explanation:
Samba.

	A samba club owner saw a literally blue Donald Duck and José Carioca walking down a path when he brought them into his club and played them some samba music. The music changed Donald and José Carioca into their natural selves and they danced along. Ethel Smith played the organ in a live action scene.

questions.text: What insect was trying to get away from falling musical instruments in "Bumble Boogie"?
questions.explanation:
Bee.

	The music to "Bumble Boogie" was created by Freddy Martin and his orchestra. The premise of the short movie was a bee trying to get away from musical instruments that were falling around him. The music in the short movie was a jazzed up variation of "Flight of the Bumblebee".

questions.text: How did Pecos Bill come to live by himself in Texas in the short movie, "Pecos Bill"?
questions.correct: He fell out of his family's wagon.
options: He just showed up alone in Texas.
He left his family because he wanted to be on his own.
questions.explanation:
He fell out of his family's wagon.

	Roy Rogers and the Sons of the Pioneers told Luana Patton and Bobby Driscoll the story of Pecos Bill while they sat around the fire. Pecos Bill came to be in Texas when, as a young boy, he fell out of his family's wagon on their way west.

questions.text: In "Once Upon A Wintertime", where is the boyfriend (Joe) taking his girlfriend (Jenny) in a horse drawn sleigh?
questions.explanation:
Ice Skating.

	Frances Langford sang the accompanying tune to the short movie and no words were spoken by the characters in "Once Upon A Wintertime". When the boyfriend took his girlfriend ice skating, he covered her in snow. She became angry and stormed off. Without looking where she was going, the girlfriend walked out on thin ice. A rabbit tried to warn her, but in doing so created a break in the ice that separated the boyfriend and girlfriend. With the help of some woodland creatures and the sleigh horses, the boyfriend was able to get his girlfriend to safety.

questions.text: Joyce Kilmer's 1913 poem "I think that I shall never see a poem lovely as a ____." What was the missing word in the poem that was also the title of the short movie?
questions.explanation:
Tree.

	Fred Waring and the Pennsylvanians performed Joyce Kilmer's poem "Trees" that Oscar Rasbach put to music. The backdrop of the short movie was done with a single tree going through the four seasons.

questions.text: How did Pecos Bill meet his horse, Widowmaker, in "Pecos Bill"?
options: Widowmaker pushed Bill into the Gulf of Mexico and that's how they became friends.
Widowmaker saved Bill from a pack of wolves.
Bill saved Widowmaker from drowning in the Rio Grande.
questions.explanation:
Bill saved Widowmaker from vultures.

	Pecos Bill met his horse, Widowmaker, when he saved the young horse from a pack of vultures. Widowmaker and Bill became best friends. Legend had it when Texas was in a drought, Bill and Widowmaker lassoed a storm in California and created the Gulf of Mexico. They carved the Rio Grande out of the sand with a stick and created the painted desert after scaring the war paint off a band of Indians.

questions.text: In the short movie, "Little Toot", what was Little Toot?
questions.explanation:
Tugboat.

	"Little Toot" was a children's book written by Hardie Gramatky before it was made into a short movie. He was a tugboat that wanted to tug a ship, but was too small. When he tried to help his father tug a ship, Little Toot caused the boat to beach itself. He was taken twelve miles out to the ocean. While out there, he saw a boat that needed help. Little Toot sent an SOS message and got help for the ship before it sank. Little Toot was hailed a hero and brought back to work with the other tugboats. The Andrew Sisters performed the short movie, "Little Toot".

questions.text: How did Pecos Bill meet his true love, Sluefoot Sue?
questions.correct: Sue was riding a fish up the Rio Grande.
options: Sue came to town on the stagecoach.
Sue was swimming in the Gulf of Mexico.
Sue fell off a wagon train right beside Bill.
questions.explanation:
Sue was riding a fish up the Rio Grande.

	Sluefoot Sue and Pecos Bill fell in love, but Widowmaker was jealous. On the day Bill and Sue were to marry, Widowmaker was supposed to carry Sue to Bill. Because of his jealousy, Widowmaker bucked Sue off and Sue's bustle kept her bouncing into the air. When Bill tried to rope her and pull her down, Widowmaker kept the rope from reaching Sue. She continued bouncing until she disappeared onto the moon. The coyotes joined Bill as he howled at the full moon every night. After Bill died, the coyotes continued to howl at the full moon.

questions.text: Walt Disney appeared as himself in "Melody Time" and sang the opening song inviting people to watch the movie because it had something for everyone, including rhythm and love.
questions.explanation:
False.

	Buddy Clark was the opening narrator for the movie and was the voice of the theater mask that sang the opening song. The theater mask and his back up singing theater masks came to life after being painted on a canvas. They sang the opening tune, "Melody Time" before opening the curtain for the rest of movie.

questions.text: After seeing a wagon train going west, why did Johnny tell his guardian angel he couldn't travel out west in "The Legend of Johnny Appleseed"?
options: He wanted to go east, not west.
He couldn't leave his apple trees.
God told him it wasn't time.
questions.explanation:
He wasn't in physical shape.

	In "The Legend of Johnny Appleseed", John Chapman imagined himself going west after seeing a wagon train pass by his home while he was picking apples. His guardian angel told him there was no reason he couldn't travel out west so Johnny took a pan for cooking, a bag of appleseeds, and his Bible for reading. Along the way, Johnny planted appleseeds as he travelled and planted seeds until the day he died. Dennis Day narrated the story as a close friend of John Chapman. FYI, legend said that the clouds in the sky were apple blossoms planted by Johnny Appleseed in Heaven.
